image.altText: Older man with grey lond beard looks into the distance through glasses in a carport

items.synopsis: Pensioner Paul Bevington struggles to afford groceries, and he can't find a general practitioner who will bulk bill his medical appointments in his hometown of Alice Springs.

title.children: 'Is it going to kill me?': NT residents struggling without access to bulk billed medical services

image.altText: Collage of three masked faces, one with a balaclava, another with a wrestling mask. They are cut by three lines of cocaine.

items.synopsis: Australians are the biggest consumers of cocaine in the world, and we pay top dollar for it. For the first time, three dealers lift the lid on this booming industry.

title.children: 'We've sold to football players, lawyers, celebrities on TV': Cocaine dealers break their code of silence

image.altText: Woman with dark curly shoulder length hair and light brown skin sits in front of a laptop in an office late at night

items.synopsis: Many Australians work very long hours, compared to other similar nations. This can lead to a poor work-life balance and a constant feeling of being time poor.

title.children: Unpaid overtime is an issue across all industries. Here's why it's such a problem

image.altText: A woman sitting on a bench near a road, looking on.

items.synopsis: Doctors told Lindy Bok she had two years to live. The psychedelic compound found in "magic mushrooms" is helping her face death, and get "20 years of therapy in one hit".

title.children: 'Really, mum, you're going to take drugs?': Lindy is dying, so she leaned in to life

image.altText: a woman wearing glasses sitting down and holding an ipad showing a picture of an elderly woman

items.synopsis: After dementia sufferer Rachel Grahame was handcuffed by police at an aged care centre in Sydney's east in 2020, her daughter wants authorities to be more accountable after the latest incident in Cooma.

title.children: Family of elderly woman handcuffed by police in nursing home speaks out

image.altText: A woman holds an iPhone in her left hand showing the Afterpay name and logo.

items.synopsis: Buy now, pay later services, including Afterpay and Zip Pay, will be regulated under the Credit Act and required to obtain an Australian Credit Licence under proposed changes by the federal government.

title.children: Buy now, pay later industry to be regulated under Credit Act after changes by federal government

image.altText: A SpaceX rocket flying upwards to space, with flames coming out of its bottom. Speed dials from a live stream.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Treasurer backs Stan Grant on racism, and SpaceX's latest private flight blasts off. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A family friend of a 95-year-old woman tasered by police in southern New South Wales last week say her family are preparing for a tough few days ahead. Clare Nowland, who has dementia, remains in in a serious condition in Cooma Hospital after the incident at her aged care home. A critical incident investigation is underway and parishioners gathered at her local church yesterday to pray for her recovery. Family friend, Graham Boller says its a difficult time for the community. "She means a lot to the community and it's what our community is and her family are all of the same," he says. "They're all really lovely people and very caring people and its a very tough situation for the town and everybody at the moment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 95-year-old woman remains in hospital after being tasered by police

props.alt: A brick wall with the words Yallambee Lodge, and a photo of an elderly woman

children.content: (ABC News)
A family friend of a 95-year-old woman tasered by police in southern New South Wales last week say
her family are preparing for a tough few days ahead
Clare Nowland, who has dementia,
remains in in a serious condition in Cooma Hospital
after the incident at her aged care home.
A critical incident investigation is underway and parishioners gathered at her local church yesterday to pray for her recovery.
Family friend, Graham Boller says its a difficult time for the community.
"She means a lot to the community and it's what our community is and her family are all of the same," he says.
"They're all really lovely people and very caring people and its a very tough situation for the town and everybody at the moment."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The latest private space flight by SpaceX is on its way to the International Space Station, after taking off from NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The SpaceX Dragon craft is carrying two Saudia Arabian astronauts (including the country's first woman in space), an American businessman and a retired NASA astronaut, who is leading the mission. The trip will take around 16 hours. Here's the moment of liftoff:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: We have liftoff! SpaceX's latest private space flight just blasted off

children.content: The latest private space flight by SpaceX is
on its way to the International Space Station
, after taking off from NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida.
The SpaceX Dragon craft is carrying
two Saudia Arabian astronauts
(including the country's first woman in space),
an American businessman
and
a retired NASA astronaut
, who is leading the mission.
The trip will take around 16 hours.
Here's the moment of liftoff:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has backed journalist Stan Grant, who is stepping back from hosting Q+A after tonight's episode due to racial abuse he has received, including after he appeared on the ABC's coverage of King Charles's coronation. The treasurer, who has been interviewed by Grant on Q+A, says it's "a really sad situation". "I have come to know Stan a bit from being on his Q+A show, and I respect him. And I think it's really sad and really unfortunate that the trolls and the keyboard warriors are silencing a really important voice in our community," he says. "And you don't have to agree with everything that Stan says, but he is a voice of authority, he's someone who reflects on the long, historical sweep of our country, going back tens of thousands of years, and he's entitled to more respect than he's been shown." Q+A is live from Melbourne tonight from 9:35pm AEST .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer backs Stan Grant, calls out 'trolls and keyboard warriors'

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
Treasurer Jim Chalmers has backed journalist Stan Grant, who is
stepping back from hosting Q+A after tonight's episode
due to racial abuse he has received, including after he appeared on the ABC's coverage of King Charles's coronation.
The treasurer, who has been interviewed by Grant on Q+A, says it's "a really sad situation".

"I have come to know Stan a bit from being on his Q+A show, and I respect him. And I think it's really sad and really unfortunate that the trolls and the keyboard warriors are silencing a really important voice in our community," he says.

"And you don't have to agree with everything that Stan says, but he is a voice of authority, he's someone who reflects on the long, historical sweep of our country, going back tens of thousands of years, and he's entitled to more respect than he's been shown."
Q+A is live from Melbourne
tonight from 9:35pm AEST

image.altText: Aerial view shows destroyed multi-storey building with fire and smoke seen on some floors.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says its forces are still advancing around the edges of Bakhmut, aiming to encircle the ruined city, after Moscow congratulated the Wagner private army and Russian troops for capturing it.

title.children: Ukrainian troops aiming to encircle Bakhmut as Russia claims the ruined city

image.altText: 5 people on a dark background. There are five circles below them: green, grey, orange, yellow and red

items.synopsis: Use the ABC's Promise Tracker to check in on the government's progress over its first year.

title.children: Promise tracker: The Labor government's 2022 election commitments

image.altText: Vinu, Akila and their two children taking a selfie.

items.synopsis: Last year, the ABC issued a call-out asking readers to share their stories about how they were coping with rising interest rates and prices for everyday goods and services. Here's what some of them say they are doing now, nearly 12 months later, to make ends meet.

title.children: 'All I could do was cry': Australians reveal how they're dealing with the cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: a woman and a man holding a baby stand next to each other smiling on a beach, they are each holding a beer bottle

items.synopsis: The bodies of 26-year-old Jane Strong and 22-year-old Eli Johnson were found inside the burnt-out caravan. Ms Strong's partner was also injured in the blaze.

title.children: Community in shock after fatal caravan fire on rural southern Queensland property

image.altText: A young brown girl is adorned with gold, beaded jewellery and colourful sari. She is smiling confidently.

image.altText: G7 leaders line up for photo call by the seaside, with a Japanese mon (gate) seen in the water behind.

image.altText: A sign showing India's Prime Minster (right) and a photo sign of PNG's PM (left).

items.synopsis: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi lands in Port Moresby to host the third Forum for India-Pacific Islands Cooperation (FIPIC), which brings together leaders and top officials from New Delhi and 14 Pacific Island nations.

title.children: India's Modi lands in Papua New Guinea to host senior leaders at forum for India-Pacific Islands cooperation

image.altText: Kate Andersson sitting at a table outside in May 2023

items.synopsis: Time is running out for millions of university graduates to slash their HECS debts before they increase by 7 per cent.

title.children: Students have just nine days to pay uni debt before indexation kicks in

image.altText: A Tesla parked next to a dark Volvo SUV near a green space.

items.synopsis: The council says electric vehicles need to be adopted rapidly, but other measures must be taken to cut down transport emissions.

title.children: EVs will help slash Australia's emissions but there are two more pressing problems to solve, Climate Council says

image.altText: Composite photo of a smiling woman wearing black-rimmed glasses, a blue school sign and a man with Indigenous paint on his face.

items.synopsis: The town of Pinnaroo has its fair share of secrets, but perhaps none as enduring as the one at the local primary school.

title.children: This primary school's war cry had a mystery word. These people found the secret

image.altText: A woman in a blue football kit raises her arms in triumph.

items.synopsis: Matildas star Sam Kerr plays a key role in Chelsea's victory over Arsenal, as the club stands one game away from another title.

title.children: Sam Kerr stars again as Chelsea stands on the brink of a fourth straight Women's Super League title

image.altText: A composite image of Zak Butters, Zach Merrett and Jy Simpkin

items.synopsis: A series of thrillers lit up the Sir Doug Nicholls Round, where classic finishes and controversy made for the best weekend of the 2023 season so far. We digest the week that was.

title.children: AFL Round-Up: Thrills and spills make Sir Doug Nicholls Round the best of the year so far

image.altText: A woman holds her palm to her forehead as she stands in a corridor, silhouetted.

items.synopsis: A new survey has revealed that 45 per cent of 1,000 employees surveyed have felt overwhelmed by debt.

title.children: Mental wellbeing falls to levels last seen during COVID-19 lockdowns as cost-of-living pressure grows

image.altText: Zane Mellor in a pool reaches for the camera.

items.synopsis: The mother of a boy killed in the Hillcrest jumping castle tragedy says consultation over recovery efforts has been lacking – leaving her feeling the family has been "forgotten".

title.children: Georgie's son died in a jumping castle tragedy. Almost 18 months on, she says she feels 'forgotten'

image.altText: Stan Grant David Anderson

items.synopsis: ABC managing director David Anderson apologises to Stan Grant and commits to a review into the ABC's response to racism affecting staff.

title.children: ABC's managing director apologises to Stan Grant after Q+A host steps away from role

image.altText: Travis Robinson stands in front of the large piles of washed salt

items.synopsis: Highly saline brine pumped from a deep aquifer on the Murray Darling Basin is being harvested for an essential mineral that has uses beyond the kitchen table.

title.children: Salt harvesters keep 200 tonnes a day from leaching into Murray River system

image.altText: Team Ineos leads the peloton in the rain

items.synopsis: Torrential rain, freezing temperatures and a COVID-19 outbreak have turned this year's Giro d'Italia into a survival of the fittest. But 99 years ago, things were so much worse, with just eight finishers of the most brutal race in history..

title.children: The remarkable story of when eight riders finished the Giro d'Italia

image.altText: A 25-year-old woman with brown shoulder-length hair, large earring and formal clothes, sitting in a restaurant

items.synopsis: In her second feature, Petrol, Alena Lodkina delivers an original and uniquely Australian take on universal themes, proving why she is one of most promising young directors.

title.children: This powerful film captures how some friendships can change you and others will nearly destroy you

image.altText: Tara Norris of Delhi Capitals claps in the air and smiles after taking a wicket.

items.synopsis: Tara Norris stunned the cricket world by taking five wickets in an innings in the inaugural WPL. Now the little-known American is making a name for herself in women's cricket.

title.children: This American cricketer is making big waves internationally, and hopes to elevate the game at home

image.altText: Man with beige workshirt on smiles at camera with hands on hips and wearing wide brim hat in front of banana trees.

items.synopsis: Australian researchers have developed the world's first genetically modified (GM) banana, but don't expect it in a fruit bowl near you anytime soon.

title.children: GM banana could save $20b industry from devastating fungus, researcher says

image.altText: a long line of police cars parked on a suburban street

items.synopsis: A 29-year-old First Nations man has been shot dead by police in Brisbane after allegedly stabbing his father and lunging at officers with a knife.

title.children: Man shot dead by police after reports of stabbing in suburban Brisbane

image.altText: A person is bound with handcuffs behind their back, with paint covering their hands. Two police lead her away

items.synopsis: The SA Greens and Human Rights Watch condemn a remark defending SA's controversial protest penalties by opposition leader David Speirs, who said that in some countries "your head would be cut off" for taking to the streets.

title.children: 'Head would be cut off' remark by SA opposition leader labelled 'disgraceful' and 'not appropriate'

image.altText: A Super Netball player smiles as she holds a bouquet of flowers, while her teammates cheer behind her.

items.synopsis: The NSW Swifts mark a couple of milestone games with a big win over the beleaguered Collingwood, while the West Coast Fever consolidate their top four Super Netball spot with a win over the Firebirds.

title.children: Swifts beat Magpies, Fever too hot for Firebirds in Super Netball

image.altText: A bright meteor falls from a starry sky. The image is captured on a grainy black and white camera.

items.synopsis: It's estimated the meteor was between half a metre to a metre in size and would have been travelling within 100,000 to 150,000 kilometres per hour.

title.children: 'The sky lit up — first white, then green': Astrophysicist confirms meteor sightings in Queensland
